column52: Storage Account logging should be enabled for Blob service for read, write, and delete requests
column53:
This rule checks whether the Storage logging is enabled for `Blob` service for read, write, and delete requests.  
This rule fails if none of the storage logging types (Classic or Azure Monitor) has logging enabled for `Delete`, `Read`, or `Write`.  
This rule skips irrelevant storage account types.  
The Storage Blob service provides scalable, cost-efficient objective storage in the cloud.
Storage Logging stores server-side recording details in the storage account for both successful and failed requests. The logs hold the details of `Read`, `Write`, and `Delete` operations against the queues.
column54:
Perform the following command to create/update the Diagnostic Settings to enable Storage logging for Blob service for read, write, and delete requests via Azure CLI:

#### Diagnostic Settings - Azure Monitor
A. If you do not yet have Diagnostic Settings, use the following command. Otherwise, skip this step and use the command in step **B** instead.
```
az monitor diagnostic-settings create \
	--resource /subscriptions/{{subscriptionId}}/resourcegroups/{{resourceGroup}}/providers/microsoft.storage/storageaccounts/{{storageAccount}}/blobservices/default \
	--logs '[{"category": "StorageRead","enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}},{"category": "StorageWrite","enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}},{"category": "StorageDelete","enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}}]' \
	--storage-account <Your Storage Account ID or name> || --workspace <Your Workspace ID or name> || --event-hub <Your Event Hub ID or name> || --event-hub-rule <Your Event Hub Rule ID>
	--name <set name for the diagnostic settings>
```

B. If you already have Diagnostic Settings, use the following command to update it:
```
az monitor diagnostic-settings update \
	--resource /subscriptions/{{subscriptionId}}/resourcegroups/{{resourceGroup}}/providers/microsoft.storage/storageaccounts/{{storageAccount}}/blobservices/default \
	--set logs='[{"category": "StorageRead","enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}},{"category": "StorageWrite","enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}},{"category": "StorageDelete", "enabled": true,"retentionPolicy": {"days": <set the retention you want>,"enabled": false}}]' \
	--name <your diagnostic settings name>
```

#### Diagnostic Settings - Classic
Use the following command if you prefer enabling Diagnostic Settings - Classic:
```  
az storage logging update \
	--account-name {{storageAccount}} \
	--account-key <your Storage Account Key> \
	--services b \
	--log rwd \
	--retention <set the retention you want>  
```

column9: This VM instance is exposed via SSH port 22. SSH allows remote access to the resource, thus if the authentication configuration is weak this can pose a major risk of an unwanted attacker accessing and controlling this compute resource.
column10:
To resolve this issue follow these steps:  
1. Inspect the evidence to see the affected VM
	* If the the VM is inactive remove it.  
2. If the VM should not be accessible to SSH - block all SSH traffic
	* Remove Security Rules that allow traffic on port 22
	* Alternatively, add a deny security rule to actively block traffic on port 22  
3. If the VM requires access via SSH, restrict the CIDR ranges to trusted ranges
column11: [{"title":"4 External information systems are catalogued","category":{"name":"1 Asset Management (ID.AM)","framework":{"name":"NIST CSF v1.1"}}},{"title":"12.1 Maintain an Inventory of Network Boundaries","category":{"name":"12 Boundary Defense","framework":{"name":"CIS Controls v7.1"}}},{"title":"T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application","category":{"name":"TA0001 Initial Access","framework":{"name":"MITRE ATT&CK v13 Matrix"}}},{"title":"T1021.004 Remote Services: SSH","category":{"name":"TA0008 Lateral Movement","framework":{"name":"MITRE ATT&CK v13 Matrix"}}},{"title":"1.1.6 Documentation of business justification and approval for use of all services, protocols, and ports allowed, including documentation of security features implemented for those protocols considered to be insecure","category":{"name":"1 Install and maintain a firewall configuration to protect cardholder data","framework":{"name":"PCI DSS v3.1.0"}}},{"title":"Resource with public exposure","category":{"name":"5 Network & API Design","framework":{"name":"Wiz Detailed"}}},{"title":"Exposure Management","category":{"name":"4 Exposure Management","framework":{"name":"Wiz"}}}]
column52: Linux VM instance with wide SSH exposure
